review_content: Pours clear mahogany with a three finger, light tan head.  Aroma is bread and light roast.  Taste is light caramel, moving to roast.  Finish is caramel and roast.
This is pretty awful for a Dunkel when u compare it against others in the style. Brown color with smaller head. Notes are cracker, grain, light fruit. corn pops, and spice. Thin in the mouth.

A Beck's Dark é rica e suave, com um final de boca ligeiramente adocicado. A cor profunda da enonia é o resultado da torra especial do malte de cevada. Ao contrário das cervejas pretas, a Beck’s Dark é uma cerveja de fermentação de fundo que cria um sabor robusto e um corpo inteiro, mantendo as propriedades refrescantes de uma cerveja lager.
Bottle, when i was a kid. Refreshing and tasty at the time. Nothing special today. Refreshing but thin & watery. That's about it.

From Jul 2008

This pours a dark brown amber with a 2 finger head of off white foam.

The smell is typical for the style. Some weak notes of malt a touch of bitterness.

The taste follows the nose. Some noticeable hop bitterness up front with a weak, somewhat grainy malt presence. It's a bit too bitter for the amount of malt that hits my palate and overall, this one does not strike my fancy at all. One purchase is enough.
Bottle - no label taken - pours dark brown - nose/taste of light metallic malt - lighter medium body

Originally rated on 9/11/08. "Skunky sweet aroma, deep ruby brown body with a very thin head, no laceing present. Flavor of malt and strong metallic notes, i think i got a bad batch, I probably wont drink the other one i got, i am not sure if i will finish whats in my glass.
Backlog. Pretty straightforward and mild dunkel. Easy drinking without any fuss and with a clean finish. Don’t mind this and honestly prefer it to the regular Becks.
Not a ton going on here but it’s drinkable at least, and a little better than regular becks. Dark brown pour with ok head. Light tangy finish. Not offensive, just boring. Bottle at press club.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Looks nice in the glass - clear ruddy dark color with one finger of dense tan head that settles to a persistent thin head. aroma has hints of roasted malts with a mineral / metallic overtone. Taste is sweet roasted malts up front and through the middle of the swallow but settles into a muddy sweet maltiness with metallic overtones at the end. No so good.
Bottle. Mahogany color with an off-white head. The aroma is slightly skunky. Flavor is roasted malt with a sweet but metalic taste on the finish.

12 oz. bottle at the Montgomery Inn Boathouse. Green bottle poured into a pint glass. It pours a somewhat cloudy brownish amber with a small off-white head. Notes of grass, leaves, tobacco, chocolate, caramel, sugars, and earth. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and an earthy, malty, damp mouthfeel. Not much to it. Inoffensive, and it works when you’re low on options.
Starts nice, but the sweet rich taste dulls and flattens as the bottle progresses. Hints of roasted malts. Mediocre.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass at the Pub in Gettysburg, PA. This is a complete disappointment. The beer is a dark brown with a tan head and has a metallic odor to it. The flavor is dull and flat with a metallic flavor mixed with some malt, completely forgettable.

Beck’s Dark from a bottle.
Dark mahogany with very good clarity. Decent head.

Mild aroma with a flavor that is a bit better but also mild.

O: Decent except too mild.
This one is way better than becks lager i had...this one atleast has some flavor to it....(#563)...

Cola-colored pour with a tan head.
Sweet aroma, candied vegetables of some kind.
Lightly sweet malt flavor, no real hops anywhere.
Some modest head and a darker copper body. Soft barley aroma with hints of coffee and barnyard. Flavour is brown sugar with a watery finish. Very blah, very Beck’s.

Bottle to shaker glass, pours clear caramel in color, one finger quick head. Slight lacing, no retention. Aroma of caramel. Taste is mainly sweet with a slight bit of earthy bitterness. Light bodied, lively carbonation, mouth feel is thin. Finishes sweet. Tasting notes of caramel, roasted malt, weak coffee, grass and flowers. Drinkable yet forgettable.
Another one that brings up memories of growing up..back before all the great stuff we have available now..this was a treat back then.

I prefer this over the regular Beck’s. It has more of a dark brown appearance, sort of like a porter. More flavor, mainly of chocolate malts and caramel.... sweeter than the regular. Seems a bit smoother and crisper too. Aroma is slightly skunky, but the taste makes up for it. Whenever at a restaurant ordering and they say they have Beck’s, if that’s the best they have, I always ask if they have Beck’s Dark. They usually won’t say off the bat, but worth asking in case they carry the dark.
Dark amber/cider color; Medium body; Aroma of malt, & some spice; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, and hops; Finish is slightly bitter; Decent macro dunkel.

Bottle at my in-laws on Christmas day poured into a glass, clear dark brown color with white head. Aroma of pale malt sweetness, grainy, semi-metallic, minimal light roast and some caramel. Taste adds some notes of cereal, faint chocolate and light hop balance. Light body, moderate carbonation, somewhat slick with faint roast finish. Not bad for a macro.

Strongly resembles a Coca-Cola. Dark translucent red with a rapidly dissipating head with large bubbles rather than foamy. Smell like many light american lagers with a corn, wheat, and spruce hops. The malts are much more present in the taste than the aroma. Medium malts and cereal. Lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Very watery texture.
Pours dark translucent mahogany with an off white head. Aroma is grainy and sweet. Taste is mostly malt and grain with a slight hint of caramel. Not much to like about this beer.
Gorgeous looking beverage that does not deliver on anything else. Distinct malty backbone but the rest is the cheapest of ingredients. You’ve done it again InBev.

Smooth Dinkel style. Not overly bitter or hopped. Makes a nice easy drinking beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
"drinkable, but ultimately substandard brew. WAYYYYY better than the "regular" stuff...more flavor, didn’t smellas bad, etc...but not something i’d get again."

There was nothing else crafty on the menu, so went with this lager. The taste is smooth but nothing to repeat the selection again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Another dud, dark but with properties of a lager that is pretty sweat although has this weird oily metallic taste but thats only if you get past the skunk smell when opening. 


Thought a dunkel needed decoction mashing where a portion of the grains  are boiled and returned to the mash.?

The term Dunkel means Dark however Tmav’y Czech or Slovak which is weird for a Bremen Germany brew.
Bottle, deep brown pour with a white head, slightly sweet with roasted malt and caramel but not much better than the light Beck’s.
Nice and strange for this brewery. The style almost same as the Bavarian ones although it is known for it’s pilsners.

12oz bottle at a greek resturant. Opaque black body topped with a thick, beige creamy head. Good malty aroma with light roasty hints. Malty/hoppy taste is well balanced. It carries roasty notes and ends with a decent bitter/roasty finish.
Bottle. Pours brown, with a off white head. Aroma is roasted malt and caramel. Flavor is slightly roasted malt, some sugar, and a little bit of hops. Not bad and easy drinking.

Has some redeeming qualities, but overall not worth your time. Starts with some chocolate, toffee and dark cherry flavors, but is upended by a bitter, metallic taste that reminds me of a dirty penny. Good carbonation but much to thin to handle the flavors.

Bottle on a little pontoon boat cruise watching Epcott’s fireworks show. Medium amber-brown in color and fairly thin. Small eggshell head. Aroma of roasted malts, metal, caramel, and toffee. The taste is similar with a decent malty bite. Medium body, light carbonation. Finish of caramel and toffee. Actually not too bad.

Medium brown, clear, beige head. Aroma of pilsner malt, tiny hint of cocoa. Flavor: grainy pilsner malt with a corn-like quality followed by a grainy/biscuity dryness, touch of baker’s chocolate, a little metallic hint in there.  I recall having better bottles than this particular one, it might be a little old.
Wow this stuff is bad. Poured a lighter brown with a beige head. Aroma was just straigh skunk and nothing else. Flavor was skunk and mild toast/roast. Not surprised though.

Bottle at Oktoberfest. Pours a deep clear dark brown to black with a thin to medium sized white head. Roast and a little bit of cocoa on the nose. Medium-bodied a little bit of chocolate touch of malt and caramel. Cocoa chocolate a touch of coffee into a bit of bitterness and grain on the finish.

DATE TASTED: October 12, 2013 ... GLASSWARE: Warsteiner pokal... OCCASION: celebrating PSU’s unBILLeivable comeback against Michigan--and my son’s fifth birthday... APPEARANCE: "dark" velvet black as night body with a brownish roadside snake-colored head; lacing is nonexistent, with a random streak or spot... AROMA: classic Beck’s ping/tang hops with a doughy funky roundness; a "dirtier" version of the pilsner...PALATE: slick and oily; lightly bodied with subtle activity at the teeth...TASTE: bready, doughy and slightly malty; light hops do not really add balance or memorability...OVERALL: on the plus side, sessionable and autumnal; on the negative, almost indistinguishable from the Oktoberfest, save the presence of extra doughy malts...

Bottle: Mahogany brown with a slight ruby tint; good clarity given the dark hue. Creamy, light-tan head leaves decent lacing during its decent. Aroma is weak, astringent metallic notes, toasted caramel malt, light florals, and not much else. Taste is metallic at first as well but mellows with time. Toasted malt & grains with light caramel and toffee... very light. Some back end floral bitterness, musty. Sharp and nearly astringent. Some finishing lager yeast. A pretty poor take on the style, really.

Aroma: A little skunky (this stuff sits around long enough to get skunked?) with some toast and a bit of caramel. Appearance: Dark brown with a thin bone coloured head. Flavor: Mostly toast up front and throughout, but very lightly so; there’s a rather unpleasant sweet tang toward the finish- like watered down caramel. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, abrupt finish. Overall: I didn’t want to dislike this so much, as I think people bash these InBev products without a second thought, but this was truly a low-rent gloss of a Dunkel, and not worthy of the name.

Pours a dark translucent brown with a white head. Nose is nondescript. Palate is slight roasted barley. There is no "slightly sweet aftertaste" as the propaganda states. Once again, this rendition of a good German beer is bastardized by brewing it in he USA. Hey, A-B/InBev, you cannot trade on reputation for long when the quality is gone.

There's a tad bit if complexity of this that I like, but maybe that's just compared to all the other Budweiser products I've had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown pour, big foamy head. Vaguely malty aroma: nice roastiness but a whole lotta adjunct. Flavor is very watery but has light roasty notes. Not offensive but just not very good.

Taste has significantly fallen since InBev took control of this one. At one point it had a decent aroma and taste, but now it is just bland. Not worth drinking. Rating 5 years ago would have been significantly higher.
12oz bottle - pours amber with offwhite head and decent lacing for a frosted pint glass. Nose is bready caramel. Flavor adds toast. Mildly sweet. Way too cold.

I had this beer about 15 months’ ago. It was outstanding! Great aroma, superb taste - truly a fine German beer.
So, a month or so after, I bought a case. Terrible decision. It was not good at all. Found out that the good tasting beer was the last before Imbev got a hold of it. What a shame. Looks to be another Lowenbrau story in the Budweiser mold.
Green bottle..... surprisingly not skunked. Toasty sweet tea-like malt aroma. Chestnut with a large creamy beige head. Slightly sweet, toasty malt flavor. Light body, moderate carbonation.

Pours dark brown, but nearly clear....short tan head.
Aroma is slightly skunked, roast malt.
Caramel malt, roast flavor...a little chocolate.
Skunky staleness....
Maybe decent if fresh.
Nothing really to write home about this beer it is not my favorite dark beer and I wouldn’t really recommend it. it does have the typical lager taste though

Bottle at ABC, the pour suggest a brew from these people that actually has a decent taste. Not really the case here, though the aroma is nice; leather, dank hops and light cocoa. The taste is dry, almost chalky cocoa with a touch of hops and a smooth malty finish. Not bad, just not good either.

Nice clear, dark pour, very pretty. However, the head is a little thin and doesn’t hang around compared to other dunkels I’ve tried. Taste is actually very good; toasted malt flavors remind me of molasses. Not much to speak of in the way of hops, but it’s just not that type of beer. Finishes well.
12 oz bottle at Billy’s on Troy Hill in Pittsburgh.  Maybe it was the iced mug but I had trouble getting any taste out of this one.  A definite skunkiness and musty odor didn’t help matters.
Dark is an over statement - but this has some redeeming qualities that make it something I could order in a pinch
Brown pour with a thin head. Aroma of copper. Creamy mouth that is slightly watery. Clean flavors overall, but not much flavor.  Some caramel and that is it. Pretty uninteresting.

From notes: per the label, brewed at their facility in St. Louis, USA.  Poured clear nut brown, with a thin, 1-finger off-white head that was gone quickly.  Aroma was malty sweet, with a very slight skunkiness underneath.  Medium body, slightly fizzy, with a brief, dry finish.  Nutty malt flavor, with a bit of a metallic note underneath.

Sad. Spent a long summer in Germany as a teenager and I remember loving Becks, Becks dark, Becks anything. Light brown pour with nice head. Aroma is musty and malty. Taste is what you would get with what I imagine drinking a good german dunkle cut with 1/5 water would be. Taste the malt and a little bitter hops. Not what I remember...
Deep mohogany pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is a little skunked. Taste is a very light roasted malt, a tad bit watery. Crisp lager taste.

Pours a darker brown color that is rather flat with not much carbonation or head to it. The scent is slightly heavier than a cheap adjunct lager but not by much. The taste is rather light for being a dark colored beer. It’s basically a light colored German pilsner with a dark brown color added. Drinks rather smooth and easily as it has almost the same texture as water. Some grassy, cheap wheat taste stand out. At least it’s drinkable!

I really enjoyed this brew more than I initially thought I would. Makes a nice addition to any end of the summer camping trip. Straight from the bottle, so not sure how dark this actually is, but its nice and malty.

It tastes like regular beck with very distinct dark malt taste. Has that standard German beer hall taste. Lovely

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
For a dunkel, this isn’t all that great...until you remember that this is a Beck’s beer.  For a Beck’s, not bad.  Light roastiness, weak body, and next to no aroma.

Dark brownish mahogony clear,short head,slight retention.
 Aroma is skunk,sharp spice. Slight carmel/chocolate. A little citrus/tart shows.
 Taste is smooth,mildly slick,slight malt light choc/carmel notes.  Some mild nobel hop flavors. Slight/light Mineral. Mild but pretty clean and neutral,with some hop bittering and light sweetness in finish. Not too bad.
Bottle from Duane on bottling day.  Dark brown with a minimal head.  Aroma of darker malt, mildly skunked noble hops and grains.  Taste is in line with aroma and a little sticky and skunky.

Pours a dark mahogany with a creamy tan head. Nose is of malt. Very creamy on the palate, the taste is caramelized malt with a hint of hops on the finish. Very smooth and satisfying. Pairs well with roast beef sandwiches.

12 oz bottle  The beer poured a deep black with a nice head that stayed with the beverage.  The beer had the taste some roasted malt.  The beer had a medium body and sticky taste.  The carbonation was average. Not bad for an everyday beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy, dark brown with little to no head.  Aroma is faintly of wet dog.  Taste is astringent, bitter, and with a undertones of sweetness.  Medium body with average carbonation.

This isn’t a great beer, but I don’t mind having one from time to time.

Pours dark brown. Smells of caramel and sweet grains with a little roast. Better than Beck's lager. Still not a great beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Happy Harry’s in Fargo, ND. Deep chestnut colored pour with a nice foamy white head. Aroma is roasted grain, but somewhat skunky. Palate is thin, taste is lightly sweet. Bland.
One of the best of the not great beers! Easy drinking and smooth. More rounded than it's regular counterpart. Extremely hard to find these days.
Pours with very little head.  Nice dark color.  Aroma somewhat of a skunk and raccoon fighting in the garbage can.  This tastes exactly like a regular becks with cheap barley dumped in it.
Bottle. Deep brwn color with head that sticks around. Bland bready taste with no follow up. Pretty vanilla in beer seaking terms. Not great

More dark lager than dunkel. The nose smells beery without and significant malt notes. The beer is deep brown with a beige cap. Bland with a touch of bitter. Not repugnant, but definity nothing special.
Taste is roasted malts and kind of watery. It’s not all that great or robust, but it’s pretty fair.
I’m not a fan of this beer. It’s thin for a dark without dark flavor, and IMO is way inferior to Beck’s (regular).

The aroma is skunky, wet mop, burnt brown sugary sweet, slightly roasty.  The appearance is brown/red, slight translucence, off-white head.  The flavor is like the aroma, a spolied, skunk like start, and a sort of burnt caramel and roast after.  The finish is skunky, lightly sweet, and light noble hops.  Medium in body.  Pretty goddamm bad.

330ml bottle pours a brownish color with a finger of white head that settles slowly to reveal some thin spotted lacing on the glass.  Aroma is lightly toasted malts and light grass and floral notes.  Taste is malty sweet with some toasted malt and mild hop bitterness.  Light bodied and softly carbonated.  A little below average for the style, but an easy drinking brew that could be drunk for an entire evening.

3rd October 2009
Bottle from a Las Vegas liquor store. Clear dark brown beer. Dry crispish palate. Mild dark malt. very lightly toasted. Dry finish. Bland!
Similar to original becks, but with less taste, which begs the question why?
12 oz bottle pours brown with an off white head.  Aroma and taste of roasted malt and cocoa .
cola brown with small head. slight malt and sweetness, but generally just watery and boring. not bad, just mediocre.
Dark brown pour, thick tan head. Malt and caramel smell. Taste is same with some oakyness. Flavor tapers off and is slightly watery. Not terrible.

Green bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, toasted malt asnd light eartrhiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of carmel, bread and a hint of earthiness with a crisp finish.
Pours a dark chocolate color with a medium beige head. This was a smooth beer with an after taste of malt.

Poured into a wide flute glass. Nice dark amber color, transparent with two fingers of head that fell to a quarter finger in a minute.
Well, it smells like a regular Beck’s. Metallic with a hint of malt.
Tastes like nothing... then a metal flavor followed by the characteristic bitter of a Berlin Lager. A big miss on style.
Light bodied, moderate carbonation.
No malt in the body or taste, no real flavor and not even close to a Dunkel. It is just a darker colored Beck’s. Stay away.

Bottle- Pours a dark brown color with a fair head that fades to some lacing. Aroma of malt sweetness, spice and somewhat grainy. taste of malt sweetness with some grain. Mild bitterness and a clean finish. Fairly light body, crisp and quite smooth. Decent drinker that goes down easy. Good for a couple.

Pour is a thin kind of dark brown with a moderate off-white head. A little roast and cocoa to the aroma, but not much, and the same goes for the taste. It’s better than a standard Beck’s, but it’s still pretty pedestrian.
Bottle. Pours a coca cola brown with a white head. Carmelly nose. Taste is really nutty with hints of brown sugar.

At a tasting in YK23 house in Haifa during brewing Brown Porter, 710ml bottle, imported, pours nice brown color with nice slightly off-white head that dissipates slowly, seems not bubbling, hay and malty aroma, sweetish, malty, hay and slightly anemic taste, light body, flows, feeling bitter and very fizzy carbonation palate, sweetish aftertaste, overall not too bad Dunkel beer.
Pours a clear dark chestnut color. The nose is mostly clean, just some faint toasted dark amber malt and noble hop aromas. Roasted and smoky flavor, with a dose of skunk.

aroma, like reg becks but more roasted cereals, some tootise roll sugary
color, meduim amber, meduim body, tan head, good retention
taste, toasted malty cereal, slighty sweet aftertaste
overall its ok, a little heavier that the reg Becks.
Bortled @ Timbers, Denver. Pours dark Brown a fading offwhite head. Aroma of roasted malt , caramel, light coffee. Taste is malt, coffee, grassy hops. Medium body, average carbonation.200212
Pours a deep brown amber. Aroma of honey berry and malt. Taste is surprisingly like a British ale. Malty with a balanced hop flavor. Underrated.
Really not what I expected, but I was pleased.  It aroma brought hints back of that classic becks.  Its taste was smooth but abrupt. I would drink it again.

Old bottle, Best Before Date was torn from the label. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours clear dark brown with some foam. Aroma: compote, alcohol, sangria. Faint roast. Dry bitterness with cheap wine kind of alcoholic taste, due to old age. A little watery, alcoholic finish. I think I’d like it when it’s good.

I’ve tried this one many times, but have never purchased it for myself.  This is the favorite everyday beer for both the trumpeter and saxophonist in my band, and our favorite neighborhood liquor store always has 12-packs for $9.99.  Looks great, has more body than Beck’s regular lager and lacks the latter’s foul grassy aftertaste.  Not much of an aroma, with a bit of caramel. Slightly bitter taste without the nutty/chalky aftertaste a Dunkel should have.  Not bad for a mass-produced dark lager, but I’ll buy this only to keep my 2 friends happy when I can’t afford interesting good beers for them.
Dark brown colour. The taste is hardly different than a Beck’s pale lager. A slight bit more bitter, but this is really not a good dunkel.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with medium frothy light beige head. Bready malt and raisin aroma. Thin mouthfeel with a metallic malt flavor and bitter finish. Not much going on with this one.
12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Nothing really special here. More skunky than I though it would be. Lightly sweet and very malt-oriented. Nothing I would drink again.

355ml bottle.
Dark brown, beige head.
Malty, quite cardboardy aromas, some roasted notes, some caramel.
Dry, light to medium body, medium bitterness, balanced CO2.
Cardboardy taste, quite malty, some caramel, faintly roasted. With that colour, there should be way more roasted notes. Artificial colouring, anyone? (2012-01-03)

12oz bottle, thanks to Andrew’s dad. Clear dark brown color. Off-white head. Some lace. Nice, roasty malty lager aroma. Thick, stronger carbonation. A hint of chocolate. Gets better as it arms and flattens, and a little nuttier. A good dark lager, but nothing interesting.

Bottle.  Pours a deep ruby color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is yeasty and a little bit skunky and has been oxidized.  Taste is a sweet with a lot of hop bitterness at the end.  There is a pretty strong metallic taste as well.  It seems pretty well balanced but average at best.
It looks great. Other than that forget about it. Skunky aroma and skunky flavor. That’s about the best I can say for it.

Bottles@the Nikon party, some big hotel, Daegu, S.Korea. Braced for mediocrity I drank deeply and took a big bite of quiche.....Sweet, dark malts, grain. Lacking any real character. Forgettable, but free, and had worse.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours reddish brown with tan head.  Mild aroma of malt and a little skunk.  Taste is a bit of roasted malt and caramel.  Drinkable.

Dark brown pour, not much head. Smell is rather musty? Malty sweetness but what lingers is a watery mouthfeel. Over priced by far considering the taste, but it’s an import. That word alone knocks up the price a couple bucks. Ok beer, but ok doesn’t cut it.

It is what it is for what is is and I ain’t having it no more! Lots of ‘funk’ in the odor when first opened and it really doesn’t go away after that. (That odor is a big turn-off for me.) Very bland in both aroma and flavor. Not worth the money in my opinion.

Tasted from bottle into nucleated pint glass. Poured a brilliant copper-brown color, not too dark, with a creamy off-white head. Mostly neutral aroma, but hints of caramel and toast. Mild malty taste with smooth German hops bitterness. Crisp lager finish. More complex than any pale lager, but less complex than a bock, Oktoberfest, etc. It does claim to be 100% barley malt (as opposed to cheaper adjuncts: corn/rice/mollases, etc), which makes it higher quality than most American Dark Lagers (Amberbock, Dos Equis Amber, Killian’s, etc.) Worth a try.

Brown but clear, good bubbly head.  Aroma has a slight bit of skunk to it.  Taste has some good burnt malt flavor to it which makes it unfortunate that the skunked hops also peeks around it.  Need to try this one on draft.

Better than regular Becks but not by a huge margin. It’s an Okroberfest in the states, it is what it is...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Coffee aroma.  Pours a dark, nice color. Taste is roasted malts and kind of watery. It’s not all that great or robust, but it’s pretty fair. Disappointing overall compared to what I expected. 4.8% alcohol.

Bottled.  Poured cola brown with a nice initial khaki head that settled down fairly quickly.  The aroma was very sweet, with chocolate, molasses, and nutty notes leading.. not greatly interesting, but no real flaws noted.  The flavor found sweet molasses and a touch of maple, with light, prickly earth around.. a little sharp on the finish.  Light-bodied and very sweet on the palate.. OK feel and flow.. drinkable, but that’s about it.
Great beer for anyone trying this style for the first time.  I still enjoy this brew, it is more on thethin watery side, but nevertheless, and enjoyable beer for anyone.

Pour is a thin kind of dark brown with a moderate off-white head. A little roast and cocoa to the aroma, but not much, and the same goes for the taste. It’s better than a standard Beck’s, but it’s still pretty pedestrian.
Sixer from Wal-Mart.  Dark pour with a small off-white head.  Aroma is weak, but kinda chocolaty and roasted.  Taste is metallic, skunky, and ashy.

Sehr milder Antrunk, röstig. Im Mittelteil aromatischer werdend, ebenso im Abgang. Trotz der Intensitätssteigerung wirkt das Bier etwas langweilig und vor allem austauschbar. 	 
Test vom 23.9.2008, Gebinde: Fass 	Noten: 10,8,9,8,-,8 - 8,36

Brown, nice and bright.  Aroma is of a grassy pilsner with a touch of bark.  Flavor is of a distinctive lager flavor, hefty hops, grassy, with only a bit of clean burnt.  Tastes almost like a light (colored) beer, and is therefore not a very interesting dunkle.

Essentially this is darker and maltier version of regular Becks, but this is more of sentimental favorite for me.  It has a distinct flavor and for any lager, that’s always a good thing, especially if its a good flavor and not nasty.
Pours a dark mahogany color, with a nice cream head.  Aroma of malts and yeast.  Flavor of honey, malts, and caramel.  Finishes crisp and clean with a little more caramel.
Mild German hops smells with dark but thin pour; taste is clean, straightforward, bland; drinkable brew

I got this assuming I would not like it but instead I became a fan.  Unlike some darks this one was not heavy at all.  Nice roasted fire, not too harsh.  A real good dark for a beginner or one who is not a huge fan of darks.
The macro dunkel. It comes in a green bottle so get it fresh. It is a decent, drinkable version of the style.
Bottle @ home. Dark brown/black body with a tan/brown head. Bland dark roasted malty nose. Skunky dark roasted lager flavor. Bitter, mildly nasty finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark amber with a creamy off white head. Nose is like urine, bready malts. Medium body with a lot of bubbles that thins out towards the finish. Faint sweetness but not much to taste aside from some musty basement notes.

Beck’s Dark has a medium, beige, frothy head and a clear, dark brown appearance, with moderate carbonation.  Some scattered lacing is left down the glass.  The aroma is faint, but one picks up malt and water (thankfully this sample was not skunked- green bottle).  Taste is of roasted barley and coffee, and there is a subtle hop note in the back end.  Mouth-feel is light and watery, and Beck’s Dark finishes easy drinking and semi-dry.  Overall, this is a very good beer.  I enjoyed it.

RJT

Many of the regional chain restaurants in Cincinnati carry this.  It tends to be a safe choice in those situations.  Similar to Heineken Dark, but slightly less caramel, and a little drier.  Decent for a mass beer.
Not bad for a big brewer. Nice color, dark brown small head. Medium body flavor and clean finish that does not linger.
12/4/10.  12oz bottle.  Brown pour with red under the light with a fluffy khaki head that’s gone fast.  Putrid skunky caramel and corn aroma with a sweet slightly roasted skunked flavor.  Mehhhhh!

Hard to believe I have not rated this beer before. It is a guilty favorite of mine, and i’ve drank it plenty during the last few months. oh well, now is the time.

this beer is basically a Beck’s, but it looks dark, and tastes heavy. I enjoy it, as i enjoy Beck’s original.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a fluffy, off- white head, a lot of lacing.  Regular grassy aroma of European macro with some hints of toasted malt.  Light-medium body.  Taste is of burnt malt and some unpleasant bitterness (I’m curious what are they using instead of hops).  Long, bitter finish.  At least I did not buy it.

He came to me uninvited though like a dummy I let him into my life, my glass, and my therapy sessions hereafter. Clear brown and mahogany under a bubbly head which evaporates into a solitary bubbly collar. Like a stopped up toilet he comes to me in wave after wave of dank dark breads, soggy bales of hay and straw, raisin and prune juice concentrate, and heavy dank wetness which weighs heavy upon my chest. Is it me or is it getting hard to breathe in here? Taking a step back, he follows anyway and like a deer in headlights I am frozen, unable to move. As his dark watery fizzy beery mess flows past lips, across tongue, and down my throat a grimace creeps across my visage to never leave. Soggy pumpernickel bread and equally soggy crackers. No finish. Old dank damp straw and hay sits unbidden atop my tongue while prune juice concentrate sours the back of my throat. Blech. And down the drain he goes so that I may be free of his bastardly clutches.




Green bottle aside, I unfortunately can say that in the 3+ years since I first tasted the Becks Dark, he hasn’t changed a bit. He’s just as dank, nasty, rotten, and blech as he was when we first met by accident in my uber newb days of beerdom. Brrr! Don’t look him in the eyes. Slowly step back. Turn around. Walk, then trot, then run away like a screaming banshee in life-affirming desperation. And remember. Don’t look back. Never look back.
12 oz. bottle. Similar in flavor and texture to regular becks lager but it has a roasted flavor. slightly sweeter too.  But not much to offer here, a waste of $7.99  I wouldn’t get again.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a small amount of head.  Nice light malty flavor with a quick finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with a large off white head.  The aroma is mostly skunk with maybe a hint of roasted malt. Taste is mostly skunky and some roasted malt with a slight creamy mouthfeel.  This beer is a little boring but is still drinkable. I doubt that I’ll buy this one again.
I prefer it to regular becks but it seems a little too much like the regular with food coloring. Serving: Bottle and Tap

Wow, this is just terrible.  Not a bad looking beer in the glass, but that’s all it has going for it.  Taste is a roasted metallic flavor with lots of skunk, and some sort of weird "twang" that I can’t put my finger on.  Making things worse, this beer clings to your palate long after you’ve choked it down.
One of the more memorable bad beers I’ve had, for sure.
Pours a dirty brown, hint of roast on the nose, tastes thin and watery with a little roasted finish

(bottle from Platte Ave Liquor, sampled 3/19/10). Clear dark brown color, with ruby hue. Medium tan, creamy head. Light toasted malt aroma, with light skunkiness. Very light toasted malt aroma. Short duration. Smooth finish. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Fair lacing.

Pours a dark mahogany with a small white head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of bread and yeast, almost a skunky smell.  Taste is similar, a little sweeter than expected with hints of molases.  Finishes with a malt taste and a hint of bitterness.  Fairly smooth, light carbonation and medium bodied.  It isn’t a great beer, but I’ve had many that are worse.

Bottle: Pours Dark Brown, with a light head as far as that goes. Tastes like a NASTY bread, nut, roasted barley mix. I could barely stomach it, but I’m not a dunkel fan in general. Do not want to see this beer ever again.
Bottle. A dark red brew with thin white head. Scent is....corn. Taste is, well not great. enjoy?

This beer flat sucked.  Regular beck is not bad at all, it’s light, very crisp and refreshing with a hop finish.  From what I can tell the dark is that beer with some crappy malt stuffed in it.  

Almost no nose, and doesn’t balance well once the malt is added.  Tastes like a stale bitter dark beer.  Finish is crappy bitter.

DO NOT WANT
Pours reddish brown with tan head.  Aroma is caramel.  Taste is sweet with a crisp lingering finish.  Very light mouthfeel.
I found this beer to taste somewhat like extra stout guiness, but with that hops flavor found in regular becks, poured dark, tasted excellent

Amber/brown color, slim white head, it looks a bit dirty. Skunky yet sweet aroma. Here goes... tastes like dirty water mixed with some sweet caramel. Much better than most pale lagers but still bad. I gave my bottle away. I have not tried regular Becks yet, but it will probably not make me appreciate this one much more.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with and amber hue.  The head was just off white and fizzy.  Smells of lightly roasted malt and somewhat nutty.  Tastes of roasted malts, a little caramel, nutty, and a little coffee.  Aftertaste is sweet.  Nice drinkability.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market, Charlottesville, VA. 6/5/10. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a medium sized offwhite head that fades fairly quickly. Decent lacing. The aroma is strongly skunky with faint notes of dark malts, raisins and coffee. The taste is skunk, cherries, raisins, some toffeeish malts and a grassy hay-like finish. Thin bodied. There’s a decent beer here behind the skunk.

Beck & Company Brauerei--Beck’s Dark Bier-Beer--2007 24 oz. Green Bottle.  4.80% ABV.  20 IBU’s?  (3.5 / 5.0)  Schwarzbier.  Big foamy lacy dark head.  Clear bright dark bronze color.  Mild roasted adjunct hop front.  Very drinkable mild sweet roasted toffee adjunct chocolate hint body.  Mild creamy malty mild hop end.  Sampled 3/2/2007.
Thin molasses with a light tan head.  Weak aroma of malt.  Flavor is malt and alcohol.  Not my favorite dark by a long shot but I won’t throw it out in the yard.
Coffee brown, decent beige head, some lacing.  Same skunky aroma as the other Beck products.  Not much taste, but that is probably a blessing.

Picked up a 24 ounce bottle and it sat in the fridge for a while.  I met up with a fellow homebrewers to share some beer and brought this along.   Used it as a ’palate cleanser’ between Belgians and must admit a lot better beer than I and others who tried it expected.   Medium bitterness, toasted malts add pep to this macro dark beer.  Priced around three bucks for the 24 ounce bottle, I may pick this up again.
It’s identical to the regular Beck’s in every way except for color! I didn’t even notice I was drinking it until I looked at the bottle.

Bottle sample during a beer festival at Sar HaMashka’ot. Clear pale brown color. Aroma of malt, light toastiness and metallic hints. Flavor is a bit toasty with some malt, caramel, and a herbal-metallic bitter finish. Rather light-bodied.

24Oz. bottle, big off white head, clear brown with lots of very deep red taints, aroma of caramel with herbal hops, flavour of honey and caramel with strong hoppy bitterness, short bittersour aftertaste.  A light and uncomplicated brew but a very satisfying one.

Bottle. Aromas of toasted, dark bread and herbs. Head is small, fizzy white with no lacing and is alost fully diminishing. Color is clear dark brown. Flavor starts and end lightly acidic. Palate is light to medium, watery with a lively carbonation. It’s hard to be tough on a beer that used to be a "go to beer"  for me when I was a lot younger.

bottled, clear cola with foamy tan head, pils malt aroma with noble hop character and slight roast quality and small amt of dms, pils malt flavor with slight grassy hops without roasted malt flavors, clean light malt residual and light hops on palate

24oz bottle, pours cognac highly carbonated with a small tan head, aroma of chocolate, nuts and caramel, flavors of coffee, caramel and moderately roasted malt, bitter towards the end. Medium to low bodied. Had better dunkles

24 oz. bottle.  Bought this not expecting much, wanted a cheaper bomber.  Pours a mud brown color with small fizzy gray head.  Aroma of corn malt, stale fig, prune, vinegar.  Some bad flavors in the taste, skunk, notes of sour fruit, skunk bitter sewage on the finish.  Well, like I said wasn’t expecting much, but this actually was worse than i thought it would be, and seems to be overrated on here.  At least becks normal and heineken go down relatively easy, this one has some weird flavors.

24 oz. green bottle.  Clear chestnut brown with a ring of off-white head.  Mild aroma is quite grainy and macroswillish.  Other than some sweetness, there’s really nothing in the aroma to suggest that this is a dunkel.  The flavour has a thin caramel sweetness, maybe a little toast.  Thin.  Nah.

Bottle. I believe I just had this beer with St. Pauli Dark. Skunky smell. Slight malt with a little toast in the aroma. Nice head and color. Kind of an deep amber brown. Taste is skunky too. Not one of my best experiences with a dark beer.
Like a typical macrolager with a bit more malt and a reddish color.  A bit better than, say, Heineken.
12oz bottle-pours a light tan hed and mahogany color.  aroma is spice hops, spruce, some medium malt-cocoa.  taste is sweet mediu malt-cocoa, some spice/earthy hops.
Maltiner nose than typical lagers.  Taste is ok but its still a typical macro lager.
Pours an amber brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is barley, chocolate and malt with some skunky smell as well.  Taste is earthy, malty with a metallic finish.  A little disappointed.
Just not my style of beer...bought this to enjoy on an icy Friday evening and was a bit disappointed.  Skunky aftertaste killed it for me.
Dark transparent brown, foamy white head. Aroma of juicy, fruity malts with some skunked hops. Taste is skunky dirty water. Pretty bad.

Name: Beck’s Dark

Date: January 03, 2010

Mode: Bottle

Source: Tasting, Cellar Ticker

Appearance: clear dark brown, wispy beige head

Aroma: dry chocolate and caramel aroma with a mist of skunk

Flavor: sweet malt flavor, chocolate and caramel, balancing earthyness

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20

Rating: 2.6/5.0
Drinkability: 5/10

Score: ** /4
Pours a a nice amber brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is skunky, toast, grain, and a touch of roast.  Flavor is roast, grain, some chocolate, skunk, and bitter spicy finish.

As expected from a green bottle, a touch of skunk. Please, brewers, enough of the green glass. I have had so many reviews messed up due to green glass skunk. Anyway, once again I will look around that and try to taste the true flavor of this brew. Through the distraction I I detect some light malt, but really not a whole lot more. Drain pour, I just can’t do it. Oh well. I’ll at least try to be fair.

golden brown in color, almost like a bottle brown, descent cream colored head and a light amount of lacing.  medium carbonation and the usual European skunky smell.  Flavors of med-dark roasted malts and very little hops.  notes of grain - mouth-feel is ok, finish is a bit dry.  Overall this is barely ok, and I would not buy it again.

A beautiful looking beer. The first dark beer that  I ever drank.
 Rich and smooth with a lvery nice deep ebony color .
You can sense the barley malt. A bottom-fermented lager that retains the  properties of a lager beer.  Better looking than tasting though.

This Dunkle poured a black colour with a nice big, foamy, light tan coloured head. Scents include raisens and dough. First sip is very watery with flavours of raisens and malt. Finish is slightly sweet with a small bitter finish. This beer looks alot better than it tastes, but what do you expect from corporate muck?

I’ll never forget my freshman year of high school... well actually where I’m from 9th grade is still a part of "Junior High" If you ask me the Junior High system works pretty gosh darned well, but these musings aren’t really about education... but they’re not about beer either...... yet.  If there is one artist that defined everything I enjoyed about life and music back when I was a freshman it would have been Beck. I listened to Mellow Gold till I had that bastard memorized backward and forwards, then I hopped on Odelay and I’ll be damned if I didn’t listen to that album again tonite. I can honestly say that I’ve really liked if not loved ever Beck album that has been released, or at least every one that I’ve given a fair listen to.  Beck’s beer on the other hand seems to have the some sort of consistency as the musician Beck’s music... the trouble here is that instead of hit after hit, it’s miss after miss. This is one of the classic examples of a worn out German mega-brewery. I will admit to quite enjoying this beer a few times in my life but looking at it analytically it sort of sucks. The beer pours a deep ruby color with a small head. The aroma is light roasty malt, kind of sweet; with a bit of stinkiness that I really never paid attention enough to notice in the past, but of course rating beer can lead to killing beers you thought you could lean on. The flavor has some light coffee, some light caramel, some light alcohol that all blends together just right to present something drinkable and enjoyable enough without being anything exciting. But really, It takes a backwash man to sing a backwash song like a frying pan when the fire’s gone
Driving my pig while the band’s taking pictures in the grass
with my radio smash

And I like pianos in the evening sun
Dragging my heals ’til my day is done
Saturday night in the Captain’s clothes
Ten horns blowing when my jewelry froze.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle.
Appearance: Dark brown color with a foamy, off-white head.  Lesser head retention.
Aroma: Euro lager nose but with some roasted notes and a bit of bread.
Flavor: Bitter with some pumpernickel notes, a little roasted malt, and a bit of skunk.  Not all that enjoyable.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium moutfeel and a medium, bitter finish.
Overall: Really not worth trying.  Not recommended.
Slightly better than Becks with a little more malty backbone to it, but otherwise very empty but drinkable beer.

Pours clear, dark dark brown with a small foamy, off-white head that laces like Velcro shoes. The aroma is grainy like a regular Becks or a Heineken, but with some roasted cereal malt. The flavor is sweet, corny, and barely roasty. This is basically what would happen if you made a "premium lager"  with dark roasty malt. Medium bodied and carbonated. Smoothish finish and on the sweet side. Thanks for the dunkel-swill InBev.  : c==3
Pours reddish brown but light.  weak white head that stays.  Highly carbonated burnt taste and aroma.

22. Pours a crystal clear but very dark brown. Thick, sudsy light tan head. Moderate patchy lace. Mild sweet graham cracker and brown bread nose. Light, flat, somewhat cottony body. Sweet graham cracker and brown bread mid-palate. This is a watery, understated beer that lacks dimension and personality. Still, it’s not really showing any flaws, either, other than indifference to your pleasure.
Nice full and rich..low key but good malt and nut taste. Slightly watery the head disappeared very fast.

12 oz. bottle from Mac’s on West Peachtree. Nice dark brown color. The fluffy head slowly fades away. Not bad looking. Fairly pungent aroma. Subtle nut aroma. Fairly nice malt aroma as well. Wish the aroma had some more elements to it, but it isn’t bad at all. There is really not a taste to this thing. Slight nut flavor at the end with some sweet malts. Fairly smooth, but nothing special. I like the aroma and look of the beer, but the taste is rather weak. Not as bad as I thought it would be. Oh wait...the bittering hop kicks in at the end a wee bit.
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours deep redidsh-brown with a thin, off-white head. Aroma of oats, walnut, and malts. Thin, watery body with a moderate finish. Nothing special.
This was a pleasant surprise, nicer than the regular Beck’s.  Colour, aroma, taste were all better.  Didn’t even know about the dark Beck’s until I saw this one in the store.  Worth having again.

Nice burnt aroma. Highly carbonated. No real inital taste, though a very nice burnt aftertaste. I neglected Becks for some time because I figured any name brand beer that is an "import" is another country’s Bud Or Coors - stella I’m looking at you. Pleasantly suprised, but I can think of at least 20 beers that are at least $3 cheaper for a six-pack and much better. If it was priced in the bud - miller range it would be my go to beer (along with PBR), as in a beer I get to go to partys and such. It is not worth buying if it is not on sale.

Draught. Low and quickly disappearing off/white head. Clear very dark red brown body. Weak berries roasted malt aroma. Heavily carbonated sour berries flavor, pretty acidic with metallic notes. Short aftertaste.
similar in flavor and texture to regular becks lager but it has a roasted flavor. slightly sweeter too.

roasty, brown, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium body,  and sort of lightly fruity.  Not very distinct in any catagory, but for some reason I drink a lot of these?  Better than regular Becks to me.

Bottle pours a chocolate chestnut brown with a two finger tan head that fades rather abruptly.  Mild sweet aroma of roasted malt.  Fairly light flavor that includes some roasted coffee notes, malt, and a bit of hops.  Slight bitterness in the dry finish.  Highly carbonated mouthfeel.
Bottle. Poured a medium brown body with thin head. Aroma is light - toast. Flavor has a dominant malty taste with a light touch of chocolate.

Bottle. Poured Coca cola brown with a thin fast dissipating beige head.  No lacing.  Medium malty aroma with a bit of grass.  Rather flat taste with a bit of roast and a bit of chocolate. Rather thin finish. Not a disaster this is cheap and on a hot day quaffable.
24 oz, Honolulu. It was on sale. It was good with dinner. Really conservative. I guess that is why these guys get paid the big bucks. It is alright. If it is not on sale, I am not drinking it.

Pours a crystal brown in color, with a lively head, rapidly fading.  The main aroma note you get is sour fruit, not what I was expecting.  It has a small bit of malty sweetness to balance that hop bite.  Flavor notes are much the same.  Really less than impressed here.

Overall Impression: 
This is not the most exciting beer in the world.  These guys and Heiny are like the BMC of Europe, you can find them everywhere, lots of people drink  their products, but you can’t really figure out why.  Toned down flavors for the masses, Euro style!  Light and boring brown colored brew.

12 ounce bottle - $1.29 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a clear, very dark reddish-brown body with a moderately-sized, off-white head.

Smell: Initial waft of skunkiness, which is expected in green bottled lagers, but just seems a bit more off-putting for a darker beer. Given a few minutes to gather its thoughts, the skunk has blown off, but now there’s another problem -- some repellent metal notes. Trying to sniff around all these problems yields helpless notes of sweet, bready malts and fruit.

Taste: A light taste of dark malts with some grainy tones and a light sweetness. Strong, unyielding metal tones arrive early on -- fairly displeasing. Touch of fruit. More filthy nickels and dimes. Touch of hops and bitterness. Sweetish t-- forget it. This one’s a drain pour.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Not recommended at all. Particularly loathsome metallic taste, like tonguing the return coin slot on an old, used vending machine. It’s like a cow’s eyeball in my soup, I just can’t appreciate any other qualities when I this glaring fault staring back at me. Ugh.

Suprisingly inoffensive, some might even say bland. Muted but balanced hops/malts. Slightly sweet. Just not much there, but it is kind of refreshing. I don’t know if those who don’t even like beer would totally hate Beck’s Dark. The only real downside is the lingering sweet aftertaste.
pours brown with a beige head.  notes of hay, munnich malts, corn, light body.  smooth. blah
It’s okay. Dark brown, not much head. A bit of roasted flavor, semi-sweet with a dry finish. Drinkable, but just not much to it.
Dark Brown with little head.  Smells almost like a bad coffee.  I could taste some toffee in there, kinda sweet.  Not terrible, but not really worth getting again.  I’ll stick to their lighter stuff.

Dark brown with faint head, carbonated. A pre trip bottle of dark lager, what more could I want, well one that doesn’t taste of cardboard for one, a beer with more flavour would be nice. Some sweetish fruitiness and a hint of bittering dark malt. Pretty average
Crushed with Jakebra.  Smells kinda like a skunk sprayed someone else’s asshole.  Flavor is like a skunk dumping on a septic tank.  No thank you.

Part 2 of my Sunday afternoon with Becks, while watching the NFL Draft (day 2). Beer was on sale for $5.99 a sixer here locally, so I figured why the hell not. Been quite awhile since I drank a Becks, and honestly this wasn’t all that bad. Great? Hell no, but far from a drain pour. 



So the beer pours out a clear, chocolatey brown color with a tight light brown/beige 1" head. The beer left no lacing in my glass, and the head melted away to just a thin flimsy head. Aromas are nice with a bit of light chocolate malts, a touch of caramel malts and pears but it unravels a bit as it warms up with the dreaded arrival of that damned metallic taste I despise. Flavor is moderately sweet, unrefined, with just a bit of wet dirt/earthy hops (maybe it was the yeast?). Not horrible, but passable and for $1 a bottle, even better.

Bottle at Detroit airport pre DLD trip... Never seen the dark so though what the hell... Maybe a mistake as this was the 7th bottle i had 1/2 of at Detroit airport in an hour... the alcohol hadnt got into me properly yet, but it did during the fligth and did i feel way rough when i arrived at Goose Islad a few hours later ... any way onto the beer ... brown ... sweet lager toffee malt nose ... quite toffee .. some lager hop  ... really not great. .. 

Re. Zoso137 ... i do wear top hats but have never had one filled with Candy

2009 Bottle - Pours brown with a small off white head...aroma is a bit metallic, but also brings some wet cardboard and a bit of dry malt...flavour is actually pretty nice, roast malt, nice bitterness and a touch of grain that finishes sweet...suprised the hell out of me...just don’t smell it...
Brown pour, medium head, low lace. Skunky aroma. Watery, with some nutty malt. Not bad, skunky, just like I expected Beck’s Dark to taste.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a two finger light tan head. Faint aroma of malts, grain, skunk and some light caramel. Flavor is similar to aroma and is slightly metallic with a thin watery body

From a 24 ounce bottle. Best by date July 2009. Pours clear dark brown with a one finger light tan head. Minor lacings. Aroma is pleasant floral hops and caramel. Taste is initially sweet molasses. The flavors are more hoppy and less sweet as the beer recedes. The malt also improves in character. Nice dark roast flavors come forward. Good mouthfeel once some of the carbonation subsides. Drinkability is quite good due in part to the 4.8% abv. Nice no fault beer that would best accompany a meal. Medium dry finish with a lingering bitterness.
Bottle. Dark pour with a one finger head. Aroma was sweet and malts. Flavor was a little thin and watery. Nothing to special. An ok beer.
Online Cafe, Detroit airport.  Dark brown body with fast-receding head. Malty, sweet nose. Taste of roasty malts. Carbonated, sugary. Watery. Doesn’t remind me all of that much of Becks. Okay.

Pours medium brown with a 1 finger beige head that has decent retention and leaves specks of lacing. Aroma is grainy malt, a little toast, caramel and some grass. Flavor is caramel, toast, some plum, grassy hops and a nice malt sweetness. Not terrible but pretty boring.
Pours a dark amber with lots of lightly skunked hop aroma. Flavor is typical sweet pilsener with light hops.

This was one of my favorites back in high school (approx 30 years ago). In my defense, there was not alot to choose from back then. I am proud though that even at that young age I had enough sense to stear away from the Buds and Millers.
Never in my life have a tasted a skunked dark beer. I didn’t even think it was possible! Leave it to Beck’s to do the impossible.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a clear brown color with a two finger tan head.  The aroma was sweet malt.  The flavor was sweet malt and a bit of grassy/earthy hops.  Not as bad as most people would make it out to be.
Brown and clear with a persistent off white head.  Skunky smell with a slight malt aroma.  Taste is not much but yeast and water.

Lovely dark color with an aroma with a touch of sweet malt. Pleasant drinkable flavor that is light enough to drink all day without ever getting to be too overwhelming.  Finishes with a pleasantness tht is not to rich nor bitter.
Hits the palate lightly in front and becomes stronger as it moves back.  Pleasant bitter finish.
bottle. has a rich aroma of hops and raisins. pours almost black with decent amount of tan head. tastes of roasted malts and fruits like raisins and prunes. has a bit of a bitter finish.

Clear mahogany with rich ruby highlights and large light tan head that fades quickly.  Nose is toasted toffee and caramel malt and some hints of molassis as it warms.  Flavor is a little nutty, and musty.  Heavy on malt.  Cloying and coffee bitter finish.  this and Redhook ESB are the only two beers my father-in-law keeps stocked, so while im not crazy about it, I guess it could be worse.
Aroma is slight coffee/mocha, pour is ruby brown with thin head. Flavour is quite thin, slight coffee and  nuttiness, but that is about it.
12oz bottle. Pours a dark cola color with red hues and no head. Smells of roasted malt, cereal and molasses. Taste has roasted malts but needs more.
Pours transparent dark brown with a small light beige head. Malty nose, not much else. Flavor is malty, with some nuttiness and slightly metallic. Drinkable, not much else.
Skunky nose and a heavy astringency, but a fairly nice dark copper pour and in general a pretty solid flavor. Also a great cooking beer!
I liked this Dunkel.  It had a smooth aftertaste and a malty taste through out the drinking experience.

Dark but clear reddish-brown with a thin layer of light whitish brown head that settles to a cover.  Leaves a sheet of lacing around the glass.  Lightly toasted malts, little nuttiness.  Taste nondescript sweet malts, light nuttiness again, mild metallic and light bitterness in the finish.
Yeah, its dark and that’s the only redeeming quality. It tastes metallic, and is uninteresting and terrible. I mean, I’ve never had a skunked dark beer before. Avoid.

Good drinking beer. Pours a deep dark color with light head.  Tastes malts and slight caramel. After taste is nice.  Many restaurants have this as a dark beer and is much better than any of the macro American brews.
bottle, dark amber color, clumpy foam, nose is skunked , flavor is a metallic bitterness with a cocoa, licorice finish
Pours cola colored into a stein. Off-white head recedes to skim surface. Slight skunk and metal.  Lasting dusty cocoa finish.
Bottle. Pours deep amber brown with a beige head. Grainy malt aroma, a touch of sweetness and toast. The flavor has grain, straw, and a bit of toast. Pretty unimpressive.

Tasted 9/17/08.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with a dark amber hue.  Moldy off-white head.  Cereal grain aromas with a hint of toffee.  Light to medium bodied with a slightly bitter yet sweet palate but a sticky sweet finish.  Cola effervescence.  Skunky and caramel.  Meh...
(Bottle).   Mild malty aroma.  Very dark brown with off-white head.  Flavor has vague hints of malt, and some sweetness, with not much finish.
Dark brown color with no head at all. Skunky aroma. It has a chocolate, caramel taste with a slightly bitter finish. OK, but not spectacular.
Dark appearance with a malty sweet aroma. Taste is slightly of caramel and chocolate malts with some hops in the aftertaste. Flavor overall isn’t too great, but the balance is good and it is smooth.

This is my usual train beer if Bass is sold out.  I hope that CVS starts carrying some craft brew!  Some grassy saazy lager notes in the aroma mixed with a mildly astringent dry nutty roast malt aroma.  Body is thin a bit fizzy slight lingering bitterness at the back of the tongue.  Flavor overall is fairly bland slightly bready cooked malts.  It could be worse.
I’m not very impressed with this beer.  Dark ,thin, almost dry. with hardly any taste.  The skunkiness is due the the green bottle packaging.

12 ounce bottle-  poured out a translucent brown-red with a healthy but short lived khaki head.  The aroma was malt with a little skunk bite.  Taste was fine, if a little sweet.  Palate was thinner than I would have preferred, and the level of carbonation somewhat distracting.  Not a bad everyday drinker.

Hoppy nose, some slight caramel.  Dark brown color, some amber notes, medium head.  Toasty sweetness, bitterness is very present.  Medium carbonation, lighter body, crisp finish.  Seemed very similar to regular Becks with some dark malts added.  This gives it a little more complexity, and the beer is not bad.

Thanks to can8ianben!  Better than some dunkels I have had but this brew is especially prone to skunkiness... I don’t know if it is how the distributors handle it but there is a sour malt overtone that I just can’t quite handle.  Some good sweetness, roasted malts and carbonation... I first thought it might be a schwarzbier.

Poured a dark brown with a medium dark head.  Aroma was of slight roasted malts.  The flavor was acceptable, though not as strong as I had hoped.  There was some roasted maltiness in the flavor, but nothing overall stood out to me.  Had a clean, refreshing finish, but I was left wanting a little more.  This wasn’t a bad beer, but there are much better dunkels out there.

A nice clear brown, almost chocolate-dark and rather appetizing. Aroma is not strong but inviting, malty with a touch of apple or pear. Flavor is rather enjoyable, mainly malty with just a hint of hops, a whisper of sweetness, and some fruity taste. Finish is smooth and refreshing.

Pours a dark brown that can be seen though under a light with a 
lightly fizzy tan/offwhite head. Actually it looks almost the same as pepsi or cola
 Smells a little skunky and of caramel. The flavor isn’t to bad of a slight burnt malt, little caramel, and a touch of 
coffee but also has a little skunkyness to it. These flavors are pretty light
and weak but it was expected from becks. Slighty smooth and a little refreshing but I wouldn’t buy it again

My first impression was that it was fizzy and flat in character and taste.  Like a bad fizzy Bud.   As a non-technical drinker, I just though, whew, this is bad.  Could it be a pilsner?  Whatever type of beer this is, I don’t like it.   Calling it a dunkel is a smack against dunkels.  I’ve had good old real dunkels in Germany, and they smoke this rascal.  Not rich nor smooth.  Sam Adams has a dark lager which destroys this.

Dark appearance with a malty sweet aroma.  Taste is slightly of caramel and chocolate malts with some hops in the aftertaste.  Flavor overall isn’t too great, but the balance is good and it is smooth.

This review reads similarily to my Nega Modelo review (same company I think), but of course with the geman hops difference. Pours a cola-like brown with a small tannish head. Aroma is weak chocolate malts, caramel and german dry hops. Creamy mouth feel. Taste is same, a little skunky though. After is not fresh or quality. not a very good beer.
A dark cola looking beer. The smell is malty  with slight hint of floral and molasses. The taste is of caramel and malt. There is lots of carbonation and the finish is slightly bitter.

12oz green bottle.  Pours cola colored, dark brown, with a light tan colored head.  Aroma is of skunk.  Some grains as well.  Flavor is rich, sweet, toasted malt.  Nice hop bitterness.  Very balanced.  Finishes with some sharp hop herbal bitterness and very medicinal tasting.
Bottle Pours a dark maple color  with little white head.  Aroma is roasted malt sweet malt and a little skunked.  Flavor is malty, sweet, grainy, and no real hop or etoh character.  lame.

me gusta mas que la mayoria
en cuanto a cervezas popularmente distribuidas y disponibles esta es una de las mejorcitas.  hay que tomarla cuando no hay mejores opciones en los star mart y vamos de paseo.  pajita pajita pajita [insertar] mas pajita para cumplir el requisito

12 oz, green bottle. Translucent, ruby-highlighted chocolate with a lasting ring. Aroma of light-struck hops. Flavor follows aroma, with some hints of metal, toasted nut and caramel trying to peek through the skunked hops. Near-medium body is smooth, creamy and dry. Worst dunkel ever, but not terrible for an industrial lager. Probably would taste OK in a BROWN bottle!!!
Bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with a white head.  Sweet and roasted aroma of molasses.  Flavor is about the same, mildly sweet and a little roasted.  Not Bad.

A little tastier then that Original, and not quite as skunky. Pours a thick brown colour with a full tan head. Roasted malts and caramel in the aroma. Taste is relatively light with a decent nutty character.

Pours thick brown, just about opaque. Large thick fomay light tan head that lasts a long time.  Very delicious aroma of toasted brown sugar, well balanced full malty flavor that is not too sweet. Medium body, Clean, and crisp. Unfortunately the corn taste comes through on the finish and ruins the whole thing.

Bottle.  Pours a dark red-brown color with a thin tan head.  Taste is of roasted malt, chocolate and is a little sweet.  The aroma is pretty light, but is similar to the taste.  Finish is kind of dry and bitter.  Slightly watery.  Pretty good, but for the price I’d rather get something else.
This one felt a bit dull. It doesn’t taste like much, outside of yeast, water, and just a little malt. Light carbonation, and a bit watery.
Brown and clear with a persistent off white head.  Skunky smell with a slight malt aroma.  Taste is not much but yeast water, and maybe a little malt.

Served via 12-oz bottle at Miller’s Tavern in downtown Chicago, Illinois. Pours a clear  dark cola brown brew with a creamy off-white head that slowly dissipates to a fine film and off-white ring. Aroma of roasted dark malt, some grassy and flowery hops, a touch of chocolate and even some pumpernickel. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation, crisp with flavors of powdered dark malt and some grassy hops. Finish is malty, a mild bitterness aftertaste that quickly disappears.

unimpressed,  I had this beer at the slipt rock beerfest.  I have seen it before but never wanted to make the purchase.  Tried it and ......was glad I didn’t have to pay for it.  Very blah.  Dark, slightly sweet.  Forgettable.
....better than the regular Beck’s, a thicker, heavier brew that is dark with roasted malts.  It is heavier in body, but less alcohol than the original, which is odd.  Overall, a great beer.

Nothing that I will look for again. First thing I noticed was the skunked aroma, not a great way to start the beer. Dark colored with a thin head and a little bit of lace. Fairly rich flavor but had a tiny, metal like finish. So basically, the beginning (aroma) is pretty bad, and the finish tastes like metal. The middle is okay though... Since this smells like a skunk and is the color of one I think I’ll stay away
Beck’s dark is very unique.  Malty and flavorful with the classic hint of bitterness you get from Beck’s.  Not sure if it’s the water or what.  Head was nice and almost creamy.

Pours a dark mahogany color with a medium tan head that dissipates after about a minute.  The aroma carries roasted barley and a maltiness with it.  The taste is OK, but without the robust character you would expect with such a dark brew.  Disappointing for a German beer.  I usually recommend a meal to go with the brew I evaluate, but I’m still thinking on this one....

This is pretty fair beer.  Dark brown with an off white head that doesnt last all too long.  Malty aroma with some fair malt on the tongue.  A bit of hops is noticeable.  Very carbonated and a thin mouthfeel.

Bottle: Pours a deep amber/brown with a vanishing tan head. Aroma is cheap skunked hops and slightly mineral-ish. Fizzy body with a very metallic flavor. Lacking in character, metallic flavor overall, and has an unpleasant, indefinite bitterness in the finish. Help support the InBev company and purchase some of this terrible Dunkel. (wink wink)

24. Oz pours reddish brown with nice frothy off white head that actually lasted a while.  Aroma is faint...some malt, not sure what else.  Flavor is okay...subtle roasted malt with some hops in the finish.  Decent mouth feel.  Not bad,..just not great.
Mild malty aroma.  Reddish brown with thick head.  Still has the iron-tinged hops taste in the palate, underwhelming and un-dunkel-ish but still has some flavor/aroma/look redeeming qualities.

Bottle poured into lager glass- poured reddish brown, transparent, off white head formed but went away rather quickly.  Light aroma of malt and sweetness.  Hits the mouth with a thin body, some malt and sweetness interlaced, finish is very mildly bitter.
Bottle. Copper color, clear. Good. Roasty and very clean flavor. Not as good as better German beers or microbrews but far superior to mass market.

I used to like Becks years ago when Bud and Miller was pretty much the staple of the beer world in the US. Now that so many better brews are available, I have to agree with the majority of the comments here. Becks tastes watered down, the color is for appearance only, and overall, it just ain’t that good. A cut above the American Lagers, but not all that much.

Pours out a very dark brown, filtered but still almost no light could pass through. Aroma was a bit strange to me. Very sweet and syrupy but kind of skunked too, weird. Taste was sweet again (brown sugar) with a light roastedness to it. Aftertaste was pretty pleasing to me though and actually one of the better aspects of the beer. Thin mouthfeel, not too much going on but not terrible either.
a boring dark beer, but very smooth. sweet aftertaste just like it says. would recommend it from draft, not bottled.

Aug. 2006 - I’m guessing this is a beer for people who don’t know what good beer is, but want to think they are drinking some "good imported" beer.  First pour yielded a huge skunk-o aroma, a smallish head on top of a dark brown with ruby highlight beer.  The flavor is thin, with a small amount of roastiness present and some lager bitterness at the end.  It’s just not good.
(Germany) Nice Dark color, sm-Head, Of the Dark Beer’s this is very mild, kind of a bitter aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours mahogany in color with a medium sized beige head.  Many times this is the best available in bowling alleys or casinos.  The aroma is mildly sweet, a little malty, and usually some funk.  The flavor has some malt, a touch of caramel, and a hint of hoppy bitterness.  Overall, very thin and watery.
For a dark beer this is disappointing. Not an appealing aroma and the taste is lacking. It seems rather watered down. Not a beer I would drink again.
dark beer kinda bitter and lacks any real flavors.  pretty boring not something i will have again.  one of my least favorite dark beers but gets an average score for me

Poured a dark reddish brown.  A little skunk in the aroma at first but it mellowed to a yeasty bread aroma.  As for flavor, it’s a little bitter with no real flavor.  Kinda watered down actually.  To tell the truth, I’ve had better Dunkels.

Well, it poured a decient dark deep ruby color, clear. Ok off white head. At first taste, I didn’t really tell much difference between this and a basic Becks lager. Very slight hint of roast malt flavor and aroma...seemed to be mainly used as color. Same hop’s usage as the basic Becks lager. It is an OK beer. Nice carbonation. Have no urge to try again....

I had this several times in a crappy bar where nothing better was on tap.  You don’t get the roasty character of a schwarzbier but the slight roast you do get is decent but unexciting.  Not a beer I have any inclination to try again.  I don’t know if they’re using sinamar for the color but it wouldn’t surprise me if there was some used.
crap. come on guys just say it. it was crap. How they got it dark is beyond me. Because it tasted like a molson. it was crap.
Poured a reddish brown. Faint aroma of toasted bread. The taste was mostly of toasted malt with some bready flavors and faint hops.
A good drinking beer that will leave you satisfied.  Malty aroma with a taste that is realativily sweet at the end.  Give it a try.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark brown with some reddish hues and little head. Aroma is of very faint hops. Flavor is very robust, perhaps of coffee and chocolate, but then fades quickly. Palate is relatively smooth. Its very refreshing and still has a great flavor. I was very impressed- much better than regular Becks.
I enjoyed this brew. Much better than regular beck’s. Rich flavor and not too heavy. Finishes smooth with just the right hop bite. A good dark beer.
Pours a dark brown/ reddish color with no head.  Legitimate malts aroma with a nice barley malts taste upfront with some molasses sweetness at the end.  Nice drinking beer.
Good flavor all around, carbonation feels a little funny. Great burnt taste about midway through a drink. Not too heavy, tastes darker than it feels.
Bottle Dark amber pour with decent head. Light malty aroma and flavor. Really not much here as with every other Becks.

Green Bottle 330 ml 
 
Appearance :Clear brown brew with medium large creamy slightly tanned head. Rocky middle.
Nose : Mineral hops with caramel toffee fudge nose (slightly spiced )
Flavour/Palate : Medium light bodied. Fizzy toffee chocolate malts, quiet thin with off black pepper finish. End fairly thin and watery. Poor malt work. I guess this is what it might be called German macro brew.
Light/medium body; plenty carbonation; somewhat malty, with evident hops; dark color; sweet aroma and taste; slightly bitter; caramel taste; not the best dark, but definitely not bad at all.

10/31/07 From 22oz bottle.  Aroma is very malty, maybe light munich malt, sweet, with a light noble hop background.  Appearance is clear medium brown/copper with a very well retained light tan head.  Flavor is quite light, bready with moderate bittering and low noble flavor.  Mouthfeel is medium/low bodied with a medium/high carb feel.  Overall, easy drinking and somewhat refreshing, but the flavor profile is just too light, like an over-chilled heavy beer.
Smooth and not too bitter. As surprising it may seem, this beer goes extremely well with Indian cuisine.
12 ounce bottle available for around $1.25 Good beer for a macro and better than the regular.
not to bad had a 12 pack of this stuff tasted a bit bitter but goes down pretty smooth after the first not to bad but could be cheaper.
Pours a dark black, but still has the hop taste and large carbonation associated with lagers.

24 bottle.  Scarlett red color and a small brown head of decent size and something metallic.  Very faint caramel scent.  Taste is very light malts, very light and hops.  Should be classified as a lager b/c it goes down like one.
Pours a dark black, but still has the hop taste and large carbonation associated with lagers.  Great for a refreshing change from the lager standards.
Pours nice dark black color.  Not much flavor for a dark beer.  Not  bad beer but again its a bit dissapointing and a letdown.

Not bad for a main stream dunkel. Aroma of caramel and roasted malt. In a blind smell taste I would think it was a porter. Pour was a dark brown with a thin off white ring for a head. Taste was mostly roasted malt and caramel in the aftertaste. Kind of bitey at first which was odd. Probably the heavy carbonation.
caramel taste with a watery and yet thin german type hop bite. very little roast in the flavor, this is not a good session beer.
Ok dark colour, with an edge of a biter finish.  A little bit of a malty aftertaste as well.

12 oz. bottle at Elephant & Castle.  brown pour with minimal head.  Aromas were decent with caramel and more malty sweetness.  Flavors were still sweet, but not quite as nice.  Definitely perferable over the original lager.
BJCP Training: Categories 3&4. Clear dark amber body with a small creamy off-white head. Sweet light molassas and corn aroma. Sweet light roast flavor wtih a touch of molassas.

with the initial sniff in the bottle i thought maybe it was a skunked beer.  i decided to give it a shot anyways.  it poured like watered down dr. pepper with some fizz that diluted fairly fast.  very watery taste but pretty smooth, definitely not as thick as i was expecting.

A dark cola looking beer. The smell is a malty barley with slight hint of floral and molasses. The taste is slighty bitter, with a caramel malt taste. There is lots of carbonation and the finish is slightly rough.

Odd beer. Smells very skunky and malty. Body is dark amber to the point of being almost like black coffee. Tan fizzy head that fades quickly. Tastes very watery and light nothing unpleasant a little big of roasted malt and maybe honey... but it could just be the smoothness. So-so.
It seems to be made for American tastes since the Germans make some wonderful brews like Spaten, Ayinger and Paulaner... I’ll only buy this if its the only dark in the store I happen to enter
12 bottle. had with Jredmond.  We both didnt like it.  Too bad because Becks lager is uber.
bottle. aroma is skunky. body is dakr dakr dark. taste is nasty.............
12 oz bottle, pors dark brown with ruby highlights,whith head,very faint nose,roasty taste clean finish ,nothing great.
12oz Bottle pours out a clear light brown topped with a off white head. Light malt aroma and tast. not great.
Much better than the more popular Becks, but not amazing. Good roasted malt taste, perhaps a good introduction to darker beers for timid light beer drinkers.

This is not really a Dunkel, not in the sense that any of the highly-rated craft Dunkels are.  It is dark, but it’s a lager, and pretty much the only taste is roasty malts.  And there’s not even much of that.

pours a brown-reddish with a thin off-white head.
smells like fermented grass and hops.
taste is lager like, a bit thicker and a bit more bitter, creamy.

There aren’t many times that I agree with popular opinion on this site. 
However those reviews who give this offering a 21 are spot on.

Not a good example of a dunkel.

This has a weak taste with a skunky aroma.
Walk past this one.

7/06/2007:  Beck’s Dark pours a fairly dark brown color.  It is clean with a loose beige head.  The aroma and flavor are dark roasted malt, chewy caramel, some hints of molasses, and a tinge of the typical skunkiness and grassy hop bitterness (although this is greatly subdued in the Dark as compared to the regular Beck’s).  This beer has a medium body with a smooth and somewhat creamy texture.  While this isn’t the best beer, it went well with my juicy steak at dinner following a long, hot day in the Chicago sun!



24 oz bottle (Bottled on 1 JUN 2007) from CVS in Chicago, Illinois (Wrigleyville area).  Rating #483 for this beer...

12 oz. bottle. Aroma is of dark roasted malt, but it seems to have grassy hop as well. Very dark mahogany color with a white head that filmed immediately. Medium bodied. Moderate carbonation. Seems to be flavors of dark caramel and grassy hop. The finish is primarily light hop bitter. Sort of a thin, dark, roasted lager. Sort of dunkel light.
bottle.  that stinky hop smell is here too.  In the aroma, taste, and after burps.  Better than regular becks.

Sampled some from a large bottle that I shared.  A dark brown-black color with a faint ruby-red tint.  It had a very big, creamy, off-white head with long retention.  The aroma was of grainy and citurs hops, but not too pronounced; maybe some caramel malt.  Its taste is somewhat sweet and sour with a mild bitterness underneath.  The body is wet and creamy, with lower than expected carbonation, and a thinner finish.

Nice dark pour and it looks good  But looks are deceiving.  A tad skunky.  Short lived head and a reasonably smooth finish.  Compared to its Lager sister, this one rocks.  But compared to other darks, it’s about average.

contains a bit of malty roasted flavors.  i tried it because i wanted a beer with a dark thick flavor, and this beer let me down.  very weak for a dark lager.  i hope to never waste my money again on it
Bottle. Pours amber brown with thin beige head. The aroma is raisin, wet wood, and skunk. Flavor has a weird wet sock element, along with caramel, wood, and grassy hops. Not much going on here.
