(24 oz bottle) Dark copper/brown colored. Decent head and lace. Nose of fairly fresh german malt, cereal, noble hops i think and a bit of oxidation. Pretty smooth, light to medium bodied, malty/cereal like flavors, bit of oxidation and a horribly nasty metallic twang at the end that kills any positives it had, almost undrinkable because of it.  This was probaly my transtion beer that opened my eyes to other beers besides coors light, now i see it for what it is. Thank you ratebeer.

After performing a double-fisted taste test, I picked Beck's Dark as my favorite between it and regular Beck's.  Sweeter, fruitier, not nearly as dry, definately heavier, with a deeper mouthfeel, and rich amber color.  Still expensive for a red.
Tastes like a maltier version of the original Becks.  Not a terrible way to get liquored.

I had to re-rate this one.  When I first rated Beck's Dark, I didn't have much to compare it to.  Now that I have tried more beer, I can rate it more accurately.  It is still a beer that I enjoy semi-regularly, but it is not quite as good as I remembered it.  Still, good stuff.  It will always have a special place with me because it is the beer that turned me on to good beer.  Update: I love this beer when fresh, problem is I rarely find in fresh.
One of the worst beers that I have ever tasted..............................
Kinda boring, but worth drinking.  Nice roastiness, nice appearance, but could use a better head.  Refreshing, drinkable dark lager.
better than regular becks, seems sweeter. not a "world class" beer, but a great drink.
overall decent but nothing special, slight roasted malt taste, not horrible but nothing special either

I dont understand why this one is rated so poorly. Has a nice dark color and poors a big frothy head, the aroma is malty but certainly on the weak side. The chocolate malts come through in the flavor and blend well with mild/medium hops. Leaves a slight hoppy tinge that is nothing spectacular, but not at all bad. I will drink this one again.

This is a good, if not way too over produced, german dunkel beer.  The problem is that is it hard to get a not skunky one.  I have had about two good ones out of twelve, so good luck.  The beer it totally different if not exposed to the light.  Hearty and sweet malty flavors produce a nice, well rounded flavor.  If skunky, it's odd tasting and very nasty smelling.  Buyer beware.
Awesomely opaque!  Not really inspired, but also not bad.  Smooth lightly burnt malt flavor with sharp, short aftertaste.
The best thing that I can say about it is that it is not as bad as you would expect.  Maybe if Beck's regular didn't skunk all the time, it would be drinkable too.
A smooth beer, reminiscent of Negra Modelo rather than Kostritzer. Some hop bitterness around the edges, otherwise sweet and malty.

You can taste the roastiness of the malt, but not much else... reminds me of the lager with just a bit more maltiness and a woodish taste. very sweet compared to the light lager, but that's a bit obvious

Rather unremarkable brew. Characteristic is reminiscent of a standard lager with some brown food coloring thrown in. Light and crisp, yet lacking in body that should be found in a Dunkel. Wish I had something better available at my own wedding!
Not bad but a little thin. A decent brew but not something I would buy often.

decent, but slightly light for a dark beer, cant drink it too often 
......
Light bodied dark beer, and thin. I liked it but won't drink it often.......
Much more impressive than the origional. Still has that green bottle though, but it did not seem to have any counter effect. Good head, nothing spectacular but still a decient drink.
Better than the original, but not worth buying a six of.....................

Rerate Dark copper appearance with a thin, beady, off-white head. Slight malty aroma. Thin mouthfeel. Flavor has some brief caramel notes but a rather bland aftertaste. Original 2.7 Nothing to write home about - but for a mainstream dark packs a solid punch.  Worth ordering in a restaurant that has no other options.
Very sweet, light bodied dark, not very good................................
A sweet, apple-honey taste made this beer tolerable to me. Other than that the beer was nothing to get excited about.

Rather an insult to the dunkel style.
Very little flavor.  Seems to be an
attempt to sell dark beer to Bud Light 
drinkers.  Very little aroma. Rapidly 
dissipating head.  Quite unremarkable.

"Dark light."   Not only a fine oxymoron, but a great way to describe this beer.  It may be robust compared to regular ol' Beck's, but that's about it.  I will drink one of these if someone offers me one.  Spending money on it??  HA!!
This is the beer that started me down the road to real beer, believe it or not.  There's just the dark hint of something lovely here and it was enough to excite my youthful interest.
I hope that this bottle is skunked or something, because if this is how it is supposed to taste, I will never have another.
A good-looking dark beer that is, unfortunately, a bit misleading. Not as strong and thick as it's appearance suggests. A slight malty taste with a watery body. Can easily be considered a Dark light.

Not as thick as it should be, but otherwise a tasty beer.  I'm kind of biased, as this is the only good beer I can get at the closest convenience store.  This or St. Ides.  So for that, I like it.  I probably wouldn't drink it otherwise.  No real strong malt flavor, a little sweet, and very thin.
Looks dark but tastes like bud heheheh. Well as said watery taste no flavor, minimal aroma!

Don't bother going all the way to Germany for this when you can taste better from Gordon Biersch. It looks dark, although the lack of foam might have everyone thinking I was drinking Coke. Roasted malt never really comes through in the flavor or the aroma making me think that this is little more than Beck's with food coloring. A slight dryness throughout but nothing really flavorful. Disappointing overall.
A bit of malty aroma, a bit of bitter flavor -- that should scare off mose of the macro-loving population, but it's not enough to attract those of us who like the good stuff.
Pretty decent.  Best german beer i've had. Not like the shitty original Becks or Heineken Dark.
A subpar dark beer that needs to be rethought by the boys at Beck's.  Less fizz, more malt would help.

The color is very muted, almost a dead brown. Palate was fairly smooth - little head retention. Taste is interesting ... hints of molasses and/or brown sugar, but has sour finish and dry aftertaste. Goes well with food.
RERATE: Still watered down, and still a drinkable beer.  This beer has just gone downhill I do not enjoy it as much as I once did after tasting several other beers.
well it had the potential to be a very good beer, but instead they watered it down, and made it pretty lack-luster.  RAther unimpressed with this brew, but it still beats many.

HmmHmm. Beck's Dark. 
Why? 
Why did they feel the need to bother? Who is actually drinking this?
I wish Budwieser would come out with Bud Dark.
Very watered down for a dark but at least it's not bitter or unpleasant enough not to enjoy.  Nice dark if few others are available.
Very disappointing.  This is the only product I have ever tried from Becks and porbable will be the last.  This beer has a bitter aftertaste and is far from smooth.
A little better than Beck's original. It is smooth and not too strong for a Dunkel. But I am sure the dark beer drinkers hate this one.
Used to be the best beer available at a pizza joint I frequented in college.  This was before the boom in craft brewing in Oregon. I'm so glad times have changed, haha.
hints of cocolate malt with slightly bitter finish, pretty smooth overall...

The Best Selling Dark German Beer in America; medium-bodied beer having a toasted, nutty malt aroma. Flavor, too, is of toasted nuts, chocolatey malt, and some hop bitterness. It is not as sweet as some dark beers that you may be familiar with, and there are no fruity flavors in this beer.

Decent looking, almost cola like. Dark ruby and or mahogany as a few others said was right on target. Lightly malty nose with a hint of smoke. Not much body, a "light" dark beer? As I warmed this in my hands, the flavor has slightly improved but still leaves me wanting more from it. Though better cool than ice cold, still somewhat a dissapointment for a dark German beer from a top notch brewery.
Well worth trying, but you can do a lot better if this is the style you like to drink.

It sort of looks like Beck's with some dark food coloring.  Kind of tastes like it to.  Really does taste like a mass-produced Eurolager with a slight hint of artificial roasted malts introduced.  Has the same vague hoppy skunkiness of most Eurolagers, with a little more flavor.
A very good beer, I was well pleased with the tatse, and it was worth the money
Much better than the original Becks. At least they put some flavor in this one.

When I was starting college in the mid-1980s, I thought that this was the best thing going. I (and the U.S. beer market) have come a long way since then. Given a choice between this and Beck's Light, Heineken, or St. Pauli Girl, I'll take this, but there's so much better in the local convenience store that the issue rarely arises.
Extremely strong carbonation with a one-dimensional carmelly (caramunich) dark malty flavor, with faint hops.  I can't really say anything good about it.

Bottle (BB 02/08). Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is medium to dark brown. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, roasted nuts, husks, caramel), lightly hoppy (herbs), with light notes of sawdust and dirt. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter, slightly husky. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, metallic. Very poor mouthfeel (thin, watery, and metallic), and not much else worth recommending.

This brew pours a clear bottle conditioned dark ruby hue with a large creamy/frothy very
light brown head that has fair lacing.  The nose is very clean with light to moderate malt notes
of roasted grain, light hops notes of grass and resin, and very light soapy earthy yeast
notes.  The flavor is also clean.  It is initially lightly sweet and bitter finishing lightly sweet
and moderately bitter.  The finish duration is short to average.  The palate is medium
bodied with soft carbonation, and an oily texture that finishes dry with a metallic
astringency.  Overall above average.  Becks is a solid brewer.

Dark mahogany in colour. Sweetish nose, marginally malty. dryish finish with some bitterness. That could be a good start of a review, but unfortunately it ends there, and that is because there is nothing more to say about this beer. (That is the long way to say one-dimensional...)

Certainly not a bad beer.  I'll echo the comments of previous raters, in that it doesn't taste like a typical dark beer.  It's a step above Beck's standard offering, because it has some extra flavor to offset the bitterness.
it tasted ok but it may as well be named, "Becks with dark food coloring", no dark taste whatsoever
I don't like Becks, but I figured I'd give this a shot. Not exactly a dark beer...but It wasn't bad. Wouldn't get it again.
Good dark beer!  Very enjoyable, lighter flavor then most darks, and a bit sharper.
Does not really taste like a dark beer. But it tastes great. if you like the german brews, you will like this.
for being a"dark"beer not good at all and im kinda a becks fan but not of this way better dark beers out good for starting out but not finishing
This a decent dark beer, however for the price there are better ones out there
Not my a good dark beer...You'll be better off with a lesser known German import

Is this really a dark beer?  No.  This is very likable as a drinker.  This is not for the serious dark beer drinker...  right along the same line as St. Pauli Girl "Dark".  It is a nice looking dark red.  Translucent not like the "real" dark beers. Has s good fall seasonal flavor.

24 OZ green bottle, best before 10.2002 drank on Feb 2, 2002. Clear dark orange/brown with a thin off-white head, aroma is of cardboard, stale malts and sharp yeast, starts and ends very lightly bitter.  This just tastes nasty, in a cardboard sort of way.
A likeable 'beginner's dark' beer. Nothing to fear, a little weak compared to heavier like Mackeson's, but simple enough. Affordably priced enough to bring to parties.
Harsh, made me want to scrape my tongue after every sip. I love darks but not this one!

reasonably good dark.
dark brown color with a short lived fizzy head.
has a nice taste of roasted malt  that is just a little sugary. 
smooth but a little over carbonated makes it too fizzy.
Straight from a sealed 12-pack, this came out tasting skunked. Thin, disappointing, waste of money.

A deceivingly dark beer with a deceiving lack of  character. Nice, open aroma of malt. Front is very short. Mid is  slightly sweet with a light hint of malted grains. Ends clean, leaving something to be desired.
Carbonation dominates the scene if left out to warm. Inferior to Heineken Dark.
Another mainstay BBQ beer. A bit more metallic and less malty than St. Pauli Dark. Thinnish.

For a dark, it has a mediocre taste, and seems much too carbonated. The head is also weak, and it doesn't linger at all on the palate. I can't even recommend it for people just beginning to drink darker beers, but I will say that you can do much worse with other mass-market brews. Drink it in a pinch, that's about it.

Below, Axle3380 got it all wrong...ohhhhh he likes the regular...he sucks...drink the dark over the regular, a little bitter and also somewhat carbonated, but $2.75 for the 24 oz. bottle is the intriguing factor.
Another gateway-to-better-things beer. Actually I like it better than regular Beck's. Lightish in flavor for the style. Good for drinking with meals.
Roasted malt aroma.  Sour, bitter taste without much roasted flavor.  Overall, a rather bland and watery beer.
not a fan of beck's dark, i like the regular though.........................
Not a hell of a lot going on in here........................................

A little bit better than the lighter Becks
................................
For $1 a bottle at UNO's the other night, it was great.  Good taste, went down great.

Would not know that this is a dark beer by the taste alone, and that's not good. Like St. Pauli Dark, looks a bit too much like Coke for my taste. Some feistiness, but dies quickly, especially in that clear glass bottle. Ugh.
The one I had was reasonably hoppy and caramel tasting. Can't get too intellectual about it--its pretty good.
Not a bad beer, but not much different from regular Becks either.  I'd takeit over American macrobrews or Heineken, but not much else.
Not nearly as dark in taste as flavor.  Mildly caramel without much depth.  Mass produced character, but serviceable, particularly if fresh.
I was very surprised at this beer.  Nice flavor & deep color................

Perhaps the "dark" is due to the addition of food coloring, because the taste does not reflect the use of any dark malts. Doesn't differ much from regular Beck's. Not one to buy if you're in the mood for a dark beer.
Becks is just plain bad. Becks puts a tarnish on germany's usually great beers. The flavor was poor.

user_id: Almeter, The Aryan God of Beer
review_content: A good dark beer, but not one of the best. Has a slight burnt nutty taste that stays around in your mouth a little too long. But, its still good and easy to find.

Very nice brown color, light lacey head. Smells very similar to regular Beck's. Tastes very fuzzy, but there isn't much complexity, a very slight burnt nuttyness. Not terrible, but there is other beer out there.

This is one of those beers that confuses me.  I seem to keep drinking it (it's one of the few darker beers available to me at the closest drug store to my house)but it isn't like I'm in love with it or anything.  Enjoyable, but there seems to be some strange almost burnty/medicine aftertaste to it that bothers me.  Hmm.  I'll probably keep drinking it though.

Not too impressive.  Deep, darkm cherry red with a nice off-white head.  Slightly nutty taste and aroma, without much other taste. The aftertaste is what ruins this beer: grainy, and off-tasting.  Otherise, not bad, just not very good.

There is a Chicago bar (Gentry on State) that I go to on Friday nights for social reasons -- certainly not for the beer selection (they have nothing on tap). Nonetheless, I look forward all day to my two bottles of Beck's Dark, and although it's hardly the world's greatest beer, those two bottles do not disappoint. Positive associations, as muzzlehatch has pointed out, count for a lot.
Not a bad little beer to while away an early autumn night.  Smooth and not to filling.  Regular Becks with a dash of malt character.
Tasted like the regular Beck's to me with a little bit more thickness. Not so great.
At least it's better than the regular Beck's................................
The sorriest attempt at repackaging I've ever seen. Comparable to Michelob.

OK Flavor, slight aftertaste that increases as you drink.  
Drank 4 of these at a party once. It made me want to shave my tongue afterward.
A good dark lager, with a nice malt body.  A good change of pace, but nothing too spectacular.
What exactly is Beck's Dark supposed to be. It never seems to assert itself and is really quite boring.
Better than regualr Beck's, I guess.  Still not very good...................
I like the Dark better than the regular brew...the 24oz bottles are cool to impress the ladies...oh god, I know that I am a loser...
A little better than regular Becks.  Certainly not a stout.  Not too bad, though.  A nice little dark beer.
Starts off nice and refreshing but quickly gets flat and mushy. Bottom line-try Becks light lager and stay away from this.
Doesn't seem quite as skunky as their regular beer. However, I think it still sucks.

Served to me ice cold, and I swear I
could not taste or smell a thing.
Seriously it was like slightly fizzy
water.  I let it warm up as much as I
could, and was able to detect a slight
hop note and clean but to the point of bland
malt in the aroma.  Still the flavor was
only hinting at bitter until it was just warm
enough to show a little hint of bland malt.
Not sure what the dark color is supposed to 
indicate, but this was just crap.
This should be called "Dark Beck's".  That's all it is.  Perhaps a hint more malty than regular but that could have been a visual placebo effect.  If you want a good Dunkel, try Hurlimanns Hexenbrau.

The beer after its escape from the 12 ounce green bottle sets in the glass a somewhat hazy brown color, the head spumous and the color a light tan, lace manages to cover the glass. Nose is mostly malt with a hint of sweet caramel, fresh with the start nicely malted, sweet and the top fair in its feel to the palate. Finish is moderately acidic, the hops light but noticeable, dry aftertaste, drinkable yes.
ehh, its ok. for becks its exceptional......................................
dark brown colour, smokey aroma, full bodied................................

Rerating: I made the mistake of saying "Dark" was not a style. There is actually a style called "European Dark / Dunkel," but it's questionable if this beer fits that category. It seems as though they use the term "Dark" more like an adjective than a style description. Most "macro-loving drinkers" call anything darker than Bud a "dark beer." I guess Beck's just tapped into that a little. Beck's Dark is actually a fairly light-tasting beer. I found it a little watery and lacking flavor. I enjoy the Oktoberfest much more.
As with Becks, quite hoppy with a more harsh aftertste......................
better than regular becks ..............................................…
Better than regualr Beck's, I guess.  Still not very good...................
I like the Dark better than the regular brew...the 24oz bottles are cool to impress the ladies...oh god, I know that I am a loser...
A little better than regular Becks.  Certainly not a stout.  Not too bad, though.  A nice little dark beer.
Starts off nice and refreshing but quickly gets flat and mushy. Bottom line-try Becks light lager and stay away from this.
Doesn't seem quite as skunky as their regular beer. However, I think it still sucks.
Served to me ice cold, and I swear I could not taste or smell a thing.…
This should be called "Dark Beck's".  That's all it is.  Perhaps a hint more malty than regular but that could have been a visual placebo effect.  If you want a good Dunkel, try Hurlimanns Hexenbrau.

The beer after its escape from the 12 ounce green bottle sets in the glass a somewhat hazy brown color, the head spumous and the color a light tan, lace manages to cover the glass. Nose is mostly malt with a hint of sweet caramel, fresh with the start nicely…
ehh, its ok. for becks its exceptional......................................
dark brown colour, smokey aroma, full bodied................................

Rerating: I made the mistake of saying "Dark" was not a style. There is actually a style called "European Dark / Dunkel," but it's questionable if this beer fits that category. It seems as though they use the term "Dark" more like an adjective than a style…
As with Becks, quite hoppy with a more harsh aftertste......................
